talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (N11) Schedule 1, item 9, paragraph 24BB(aa), after "other than" (wherever occurring), insert "the validation of".
(N12) Schedule 1, item 9, page 22 (after line 31), after paragraph (e), insert:
(ea) the consequences of any act with respect to which an agreement can be made (other than the validation of past acts or intermediate period acts);
(N13) Schedule 1, item 9, paragraph 24CB(aa), after "other than" (wherever occurring), insert "the validation of".
(N14) Schedule 1, item 9, page 26 (after line 16), after paragraph (e), insert:
(ea) the consequences of any act with respect to which an agreement can be made (other than the validation of past acts or intermediate period acts);
(N15) Schedule 1, item 9, paragraph 24DB(aa), after "other than" (wherever occurring), insert "the validation of".
(N16) Schedule 1, item 9, page 35 (after line 23), after paragraph (e), insert:
(ea) the consequences of any act with respect to which an agreement can be made (other than the validation of past acts or intermediate period acts);

These amendments relate to body corporate agreements, area agreements and alternative agreements. In short, the government's policy is to ensure that ILUAs cannot be used to validate past and intermediate period acts. However, as I said earlier, we believe that the government amendments go further and they limit ILUAs to compensation issues only. We believe that it should be left open as to whether an ILUA can deal with the extinguishment regarding past and intermediate period acts. Agreements are voluntary and we think the question of extinguishment should be left open for the process. This applies with respect to the three sorts of agreements—the body corporates, the alternative agreements and the area agreements.

The other impact of our amendments is to ensure that, although government policy is given effect and corporate agreements cannot validate past and intermediate period acts, the extinguishment issue can be dealt with. That is the first point. The second point is that we should provide a capacity for area agreements, alternative agreements and body corporate agreements to deal with compensation issues arising from past and intermediate period acts. The government does not provide for compensation issues arising from past and intermediate period acts to be dealt with. We believe that they can be. It is a very limited add-on to the government's provisions and does not in any way impact on the validation process adopted by the government.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —As I understand it, the proposition is that parties should be able to agree to, in effect, undo what the bill says about the effect of past acts or intermediate period acts upon native title, which is not a suggestion we are able to take up. It should be remembered and recognised that, in terms of future acts, agreement can be reached as to the effect of future acts on native title. But to try to put in place a regime which somehow can, in a sense, undermine or affect what the act otherwise says about the effect of past acts or intermediate period acts on native title does not seem a principle that we could endorse.

speech.para: I would point out, as we said before, that in this validation area we are dealing almost overwhelmingly with mining leases which are, of course, subject to the non-extinguishment principle. They do not actually extinguish as in the current act. Mining leases are a non-extinguishing grant, and that continues, and that is recognised in the validation regime, and overwhelmingly that is what we are talking about. In practice, I am not sure what would be achieved by this.

We also draw to the Senate's attention our amendments last time of 47A and 47B to ensure that past grants of exclusive possession on lands occupied by Aboriginal people can be ignored for the purposes of determining their native title claims. I think we have specifically dealt with occasions on which issues may arise as to the effect of prima facie past extinguishment in a sensible and practical way, but we think this does go just a little too far.

talk.start.para: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I indicate that the Greens (WA) will be supporting the Labor amendments here.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, are we dealing at the present moment with N11 only, or are we also dealing with—
—The group from N11 through to N15.

—Thank you. I will pick out one particular provision in the opposition amendments. Amendment N12 deals with schedule 1, item 9, which inserts this provision in that particular schedule on page 22 relating to the coverage of body corporate agreements:

speech.para: The agreement must be about one or more of the following matters in relation to an area:
Then the addition that N12 is suggesting is this:
(ea) The consequences of any act with respect to which an agreement can be made (other than the validation of past acts or intermediate period acts);

When you look through government provision 24BB, it says you can deal with the acts, but I cannot see why you cannot deal with the consequences of the acts. If you can deal with the acts, why can't you deal with the consequences of the acts?

I would like the government to explain why they refuse to accept that amendment of the opposition when in fact paragraph (f), which deals with matters which can be covered by body corporate agreements, says:
(f) any other matter concerning native title rights and interests in relation to the area.
That is now the government's proposal. Why will the government not accept opposition amendment N12, just as an example?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —As I have previously explained, the problem is that it purports to enable, by agreement, the undoing of the legal effect of the bill in relation to validation without providing a mechanism thereby to effect that undoing. We are talking about the bill presented and the bill becoming an act in terms of the whole scheme of the act, and it provides for consequences of validation as in the current act—a category A to D effect of validation—and that is what applies.

speech.para: This provision purports to enable parties to agree to vary that effect without, in our view, providing the legal mechanism by which you do undo what the bill would provide in relation to validation. The bill says clearly what shall happen as a result of the validation of certain acts in respect of the effect on native title, and that is the category A to D impact.

But then this add-on of allowing parties to agree in a sense to vary what is provided by statute to be the effect seems to us not to achieve what is being sought and to run into significant legal difficulty. I have to say, perhaps, if this had been able to be discussed some time before, it may have been possible that we could have discussed a way in which whatever the objective is could have been reached, but we do not think this will do it, and it does run into the brick wall of what the bill otherwise provides. It cannot really be allowed to be undone, and it is not able to be undone in this way in our view.

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Harradine has a valid point. If you look, for instance, at paragraph (f) on page 23 of the amendments, it is a very broad sweep:

speech.para: any other matter concerning native title rights and interests in relation to the area.

We are seeking to incorporate consideration of the consequences of any act with respect to which an agreement can be made. Can I say to you that we explicitly exclude the question of validation. If you were to keep reading to the end of paragraph (ea), it says:
. . . . (other than the validation of past acts or intermediate period acts);

In a sense, one could argue that our paragraph (ea) is in fact more limited than your paragraph (f), because there is no such exclusion from (f). I would ask the government to reconsider its position here. It is an amendment which, as I say, is more limited in application than paragraph (f), but one which I think the government should pick up.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —This is getting highly legalistic, but it is our interpretation of this provision that it would purport to allow agreement about the consequences of validation. Admittedly, it does exclude agreements about the validation per se, but there is a difference between seeking to reach agreement about whether something is validated or not, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, seeking to reach agreement about what the consequences of that validation are.

speech.para: The way that this is expressed, clearly, to our legal advisers, suggests that it remains open to parties to agree about the consequences of the validation, which we, as I say, do not believe can be given effect to, given that the parties must operate in terms of these indigenous land use agreements within the framework of the act and cannot agree, unless specifically stated and allowed for in the bill, to sweep away the law or agree that the law should not apply to them. That is, of course, how (f) should be read. `Any other native title rights and interests', sure, but within the context of the bill and the legal framework provided in the bill. They cannot agree just to decide which parts of the law shall or shall not apply to them.

Maybe the opposition is not intending to draw this distinction in N12, but clearly, on our legal advice, there is a distinction that while it does remove the capacity to agree about validation per se, it does not remove the purported right to agree about the consequences.

talk.start.para: —I do not think you can have it both ways here, Senator Minchin. If (f) is to apply within the context of the law, then (ea) is also to apply within the context of the law, because they are all part of 24BB and they are all governed by the same framework of the law. The point I make to you—maybe I should let Senator Harradine pursue this as well, if he wants to—is that, in the same way that (f) is going to be governed by the framework of the law, so is (ea). Also, given the fact that governments are parties to this extinguishment process, you have the other fall-back position that you obviously would not be discussing the validation of past or intermediate period acts.

speech.para: Your (f) is broader than our (ea). If they are all working under the same framework, I do not know why the consequences of an act cannot be taken into account, although any other matter concerning native title rights and interests can be.

talk.start.para: —I would like to add a little to that point. Perhaps you can respond to both of us at the same time, Minister. The indigenous land use agreements can actually remove rights that indigenous people have under the act. It is all very well to say that people cannot move to change rights that benefit other people, but the reality is that perhaps you are making it a one-way street and saying that indigenous land use agreements can only remove rights for indigenous people but cannot alter other rights established under the acts.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —With respect, Senator Bolkus, the ALP cannot have it both ways, either. As we understand it, the intention is to allow parties to agree to vary the consequences of validation. If that is the intention, it runs contrary to the bill—and, hopefully, the act, as amended—as to the consequences of validation. So if that is your purpose, this will not achieve it. You would have to amend other parts of the bill relating to the effect of validation.

speech.para: If you do not intend this to mean that parties can agree to vary the consequences of validation, then it is not needed because, as you say, you have got (f)—any other matter concerning native title rights and interests can be agreed to, but obviously within the framework of the act, as amended. That is why we suggest to you that it is not going to achieve what we understand to be your purpose and is not a purpose that we believe should be able to be achieved.

talk.start.para: —There is sufficient confusion in my mind that there may need to be some other amendments to achieve the particular objective. I did raise paragraph (f) and pointed out that the agreements can be about any other matter concerning native title rights and interests in relation to the area. I think we all hope that the ILUAs will be a very significant part of the process of achieving just and fair outcomes. I am somewhat confused about the question that has been raised—as to whether what is being sought to be achieved by the opposition amendments may not be achieved unless there is an amendment in relation to the provisions, the consequences, of validation.

—I suggest that the amendments be deferred until later today or tomorrow. As I said to Senator Minchin yesterday, when we said we would give a commitment that this bill would be through before Easter, I did not mention to him that I am of the Greek Orthodox faith and our Easter is next week, so we might have a bit longer to deliberate on this.

speech.para: Progress reported.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.46 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. Minister, is it a fact that your department's youth and student communication team has produced a youth allowance media strategy which listed the main negative aspects of your youth allowance as being: firstly, that unemployed over-18s will still be financially dependent on their families until they are 21 and families will now have to support their young unemployed for another two years; secondly, youth allowance will cause more family disputes and encourage family breakdown; thirdly, youth allowance will cause young people to leave home and leave the security of family support; fourthly, youth allowance will cause more youth homelessness; and fifthly, $23,000 is not a lot of money before youth allowance starts to cut out because of the parental income test. Minister, wouldn't it be more appropriate for you to focus your energies on rectifying these clearly specified negative aspects of your youth allowance, rather than wasting time and taxpayers' money trying to sell the Australian people a dud?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I did not notice Senator Crowley getting too involved in the debate about the youth allowance when it came through the Senate—obviously she wants to run with the hares and hunt with the hounds. As a matter of fact, senators would recognise that the lines that Senator Crowley was using just now were the allegations that were being made by some of her fellow travellers as we approached the debate. Those lines are still being run. It is a wonder you did not add, Senator, that students are going to be seriously disadvantaged—but, of course, that was a National Union of Students line and the NUS have been lobbying for 20-odd years to get rent assistance eligibility for students. It is a wonder you did not include that.

answer.para: In fact, Senator—to deal with the allegations of some of your mates—it is sensible for the government to prepare information for people to demonstrate how wrong they are. You would know that, because the debate took about 20 hours in the Senate just a couple of weeks ago. These matters were explored at length. It is very important that families do take responsibility for their children while they are financially dependent. You decided to do that for students up to the age of 22. Now, students up to the age of 25 are parentally means tested. Are you suggesting—certainly the government does not—that people who are unemployed should not also be supported by their parents, to the extent that those parents are able?

Getting to the means test that you referred to in your question, Senator, you may have forgotten that that was the starting point of your Austudy means test. We have not only adopted it, we have made it more generous. Why should we put into place more generous proposals for those who are unemployed than for those who are students? We have given young people of similar ages and similar financial circumstances the same treatment. We are about encouraging young people to get the skills they need so that they are employable.

It is very interesting to notice that the Australian opposition are going backwards on these sorts of social policy matters except, perhaps, for one or two of your young Turks. Your contemporaries in Britain are saying this is the route to go. We cannot condemn young people to a life of long-term unemployment. They and their parents need to be encouraged to understand that skill-less jobs are disappearing all around the world. In Australia, we must make sure that our young people do acquire the skills so that they do not spend a long time in unemployment.

In addition, we believe that those who are unemployed and those who are students should have the same financial assistance. There should not be an incentive to be unemployed. If you want to talk about the youth allowance, Senator Crowley, I would be happy to talk to you about it any time. It is an excellent social policy measure. It is real reform which is badly overdue. It certainly makes it easier for families and for young people to access the entitlements that they have, because the system that we inherited from you was so complex that people fell between the cracks of their entitlement and they did not always know that they were entitled. We have improved that for young people, and that is a major reform.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it true that your department is dedicating an officer to you and your office for the specific purposes of monitoring the media on youth allowance issues and providing you and your office with appropriate responses to the rising criticism of it? Minister, how do you justify this abuse of taxpayer funded resources, given that your personal staff allotment is already 15 people?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I have not the faintest idea whether they have allocated somebody in the department to monitor these things. That is not a matter that has been brought to my attention. My office has a very efficient work force that has been monitoring the media on this issue and answering it very effectively. I do not know that there is anybody else dedicated to it.

—My question is also to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, Australians want a social security system which is fair and equitable and which looks after those with a genuine entitlement to assistance. What action has the government taken to improve the integrity of the social security system and to ensure that payments only go to those who are entitled to them? In particular, what is the government's record in recovering money which has been paid to people who are not entitled to it?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I am grateful to Senator Ferris for that question because it is one that we will never hear from the opposition. Once again it is an area where they were not prepared to take leadership. They were not prepared to introduce reforms, and I am talking about making sure that our social security system has integrity, particularly in the eyes of those who fund it and who must give it support.

answer.para: The Labor Party said we could not do the cleansing of the social security system. They said we were wrong when we said that there was plenty of room to improve compliance in the social security system. Labor told everybody they had cleaned out the cheating. Labor's Minister for Social Security told the House on 12 October 1994 that an independent review of the system found that the compliance problem was `effectively solved'. Labor claimed its system was at the `cutting edge' in terms of combating fraud and compliance problems.

Under Labor, the cutting edge must have been very blunt. Today I will present the second quarterly report on social security compliance activity for the first six months of the 1997-98 financial year. More than 1½ million entitlement reviews were carried out between July and December 1997. Over 171,000 people in that time had their social security payments cancelled or reduced—a 25 per cent increase on the same period in 1996-97—which means that we are saving $13 million more a week on payments that we do not have to make for the remainder of this financial year.

During this six-month period, 1,319 people were convicted in the courts for welfare fraud. We have increased our recovery of outstanding debts by over 31 per cent to $230 million during the first six months of 1997-98. During the 18 months to December 1997 the coalition government has recovered more than $600 million in debts owed by people who have received more than their entitlement.

talk.start.para: —It is staggering.

—It is staggering. But get this: we have been getting back about $1.1 million a day under this government for that period. That is a 76 per cent increase over the amount of debt recovered under the last 18 months of Labor.
—They are quiet now.
—Very quiet, and they talked about being at the cutting edge. It is important that people understand the importance of this recovery of debt.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I see they do not want anybody to hear this. If you try to claim social security payments which you are not entitled to, we not only stop the payment, we also make you repay the money you have wrongfully received. Today I want to commend heartily the efforts of the staff in Centrelink who have responded so well to this government's focus on improving compliance and stamping out fraud. Their efforts clearly demonstrate the importance of leadership by government on this issue, leadership which was sadly lacking under the previous Labor government.

answer.para: Our efforts are strongly supported by Australians. During the first six months of this financial year there were 27,447 public tip-offs which led to 7,400 payment cancellations or reductions. That is a 31 per cent increase on the same period last year, because Australians recognise the need for a social security system with integrity. It protects those who are genuinely in need of assistance and it demonstrates to those who fund the system, the taxpayers, that their money is spent carefully and on those who are entitled to help. For the small number of people who still have the misguided view that social security is easy money, it is not a matter of if but when they will be caught. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, thank you for that comprehensive response. You made reference in your answer to the leadership of the coalition government in cracking down on fraud and non-compliance in social security. Could you tell the Senate how this government's record compares with that of the previous government?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris for her supplementary question.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is clear that the opposition do not want to hear the answer to that either, because the figures in the report which I am tabling today are proof that Labor is not interested and that we have put our words into action. We put in the resources, we gave the leadership, and the Social Security and Centrelink staff responded to the task. They were very heartened by the fact that at last they had a government that was prepared to take action in an area which they believed needed serious attention.

answer.para: The previous government had 13 years to improve compliance and clean up the system, and all we got from them was rhetoric. We got no leadership, we got no resources going into the job. When he was Minister for Social Security, Brian Howe said, `If there have been problems in terms of social security fraud and overpayments, let me say that this government has done more to tackle those problems than any previous government.' What a lot of codswallop. When Graham Richardson was minister, he announced an amnesty, for goodness' sake. That is the sort of leadership they got under Labor. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Kiribati led by the Hon. Teiraoi Tetabea. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the chamber and trust that your visit to this country will be informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. Minister, will you confirm that your department's youth allowance media strategy suggested that you identify young members and senators who could act as `ambassadors' for your youth allowance? Have you appointed any ambassadors as yet? Did you accept your department's advice that their role was `to try to counteract negative publicity being spread by Natasha Stott Despoja and Jenny Macklin?' Minister, how do you justify your department taking such a highly political role in this matter?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —The question is from a member of a former government that spent money like water on a whole lot of things, including advertisements. Do you remember the Working Nation advertisements? Do you remember the superannuation advertisements? Do you remember the bread and the circuses that were paid for by the taxpayer on behalf of Mr Keating, Mr Beazley and other people sitting opposite?

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is too much intervention.

—What I will be doing is selling a most excellent social policy reform and explaining the details of what has been a major reform of turning five payments paid by two departments at 13 different rates into one payment paid by Centrelink.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—We have something very good to explain to the Australian people. But some of the friends of the Labor Party—and by that I include some of the minor parties in this place; no names no pack drill, of course—do not like to see this government taking such a pro-active role in social security reform. They do not like to see us making sure that students are on an equal level with the young unemployed. They do not like to see us giving incentives to young people to study. They are sometimes very careless with the truth—that might be a way of putting it.

answer.para: I do not apologise in any shape or form for making sure that young people and their families, and the communities in which they live, are properly informed about the important social policy reform called the youth allowance. It is a vitally important measure. Those of you who have the good fortune to live in regional Australia would understand full well the importance of families being able to afford to send their young people away to study. In the case of children who go away to study to acquire skills, rent assistance will be a huge improvement for families with more than one child in particular.
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections in the chamber.

—I may be being unkind to the opposition, but I seem to have notice a cacophony of sound whenever I endeavour to put on the record just how important these reforms are to Australia. They are not only important to young Australians; they are also important to their parents and they are important to the communities they live in. Do you want to condemn young people to live in regional towns where there is little work unless they are skilled and where they cannot afford to go away to study and acquire those skills? If that is what you stand for, speak up, because that is what I think you stand for.

answer.para: As far as ambassadors are concerned, all my colleagues will be ambassadors for the youth allowance and I will tell you why: because some of us have grey hair and grandchildren and we are thinking of the future. Some of us are parents and are thinking about our kids' current life.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise in the chamber is absolutely unacceptable and behaviour is in breach of the standing orders.

—The opposition fail to acknowledge that we are proud of this reform. We think it is a major important initiative that is going to help our country and help our kids. We would be happy for everybody to sing its praises. I invite you to join us because some of you are young, some of you have grey hair and some of you are just in the middle, and this will be important for our country for years to come. So be ambassadors. You won't get paid, but you will do something for your country, at last.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am glad, Minister, that you have acknowledged the role of Senators Crane and Lightfoot, et cetera, as ambassadors for this program. Minister, is it true that the media strategy refers to the need to `negotiate with television producers to include a storyline on a television show like Home and Away or Neighbours '? Minister, isn't the department showing undue sensitivity in omitting a storyline on a series such as Keeping Up Appearances ?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —Senator Calvert says the opposition looks more like the Adams Family over there, especially the Leader of the Opposition.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of intervention is absolutely unacceptable. It is impossible to hear what is going on. There are many senators behaving in a way that is in breach of the standing order, some of them persistently and I think some of them wilfully. I shall take note of that.

—It may surprise the opposition that I do not really have much time for watching soapies. Obviously you have a lot of time on your hands just at the moment. If there is any advice coming to me from those who are expert in the field, I will be glad to study it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Minister, last night during the adjournment debate, Senator Robert Ray alleged that two members of parliament had generated false receipts, presumably for tax purposes. What is your response to these claims? Are the Australian Federal Police investigating these claims? Is it an offence to destroy evidence or to urge others to do so?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Coonan for a particularly astute question. Yes, Senator Ray did make some very serious inferences, I will say, in the Senate last night. I have subsequently had a discussion with Senator Ray about that. Senator Ray puts the case that he did not specifically allege that two senators had committed fraud. But what he did say was that certain conduct had taken place and the only purpose for which he could assume it was done was for taxation purposes. So an inference or an allegation: I am happy to give way to what Senator Ray suggests in that respect. But what he has suggested is that two MPs have used their computers to generate false receipts for tax purposes. In raising these allegations in this chamber before the appropriate authorities were notified, Senator Ray has behaved in a most irresponsible fashion.

answer.para: The proper course of action for Senator Ray would have been to raise the matter with the appropriate authorities and then to remain silent until an investigation was complete. It is well understood what happens. If you say to someone who is perpetrating criminal conduct, `Hey, by the way, I've just told the cops what you're doing and they'll be round to get in a minute,' what do you think they are going to do? They are going to cease the conduct and get rid of the evidence. Senator Ray is an experienced senator in this place. He has been a minister and a cabinet minister. He understands full well the consequences for law enforcement of tipping off criminals in advance of an investigation. He understands the consequences of that very clearly.

Today I have referred these matters to the Australian Federal Police. I have some reason to believe that they have today been referred to the Australian tax office for investigation. But I might say I suspect it is too late. Senator Ray was in this place last night and he had this to say. This is all under privilege, so he does not have to worry. He would not be treated like a normal citizen. This is under privilege in what he used to refer to as the coward's castle. He said:

. . . I am not going to name the two members . . . but I do think their colleagues might have a yap about and might drop broad hints that this should be taken off the hard drive, as Senator Faulkner says, and that this particular practice should cease.

What will Senator Ray say? He will say, `I was trying to stop the criminal conduct.' As I read this, he said to people on this side, `Why don't you go and tip somebody off to destroy the evidence, to destroy some evidence.' It is an offence to incite, to urge, aid or encourage someone to commit an offence under the Crimes Act. It is an offence to destroy evidence that might be used in a criminal proceeding with the intent thereby to prevent it from being used in evidence.

I accept that Senator Ray will probably say—and it is in keeping with his normal demeanour in this place and normal commitment to the proper processes being undertaken—that he was not seeking to get people to destroy evidence so that it could not be used in court proceedings, and I would accept that. But I have to say, Senator Ray, that, if you were a normal citizen and you did not have the protection of privilege, you may well have to be arguing that in court. You would have to say why it was that you thought it was appropriate to tip the alleged criminals off and then say, `And, by the way, there's some evidence that might be key evidence. You don't have to destroy all of it, just some that might be used,' and then say, `Look, why don't you get it off your hard disc,' with all the opportunities that that takes away from law enforcement. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, is it true that some of the miners in Cobar and Goulburn who have lost their jobs as a result of the mine closures have still not received their entitlements to unemployment benefit? How can this be so when you have given—
—Pass the Wik bill and they will get jobs.

—Senator, we are talking about people who have lost their jobs here. Why don't you just keep quiet and listen. Minister, how can this be so when you have given repeated assurances that there will be no further delays? Minister, don't you have the capacity within your portfolio to provide emergency assistance to these miners and their families in the same way, for example, that Commonwealth emergency payment was made to the victims of the Katherine floods?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —As at 26 March, 209 claims for social security payments had been lodged by former employees of the mine at Cobar. All claims have been processed with 199 being granted payment. On Friday, 20 March the administrator of the mine announced that it would be able to pay out former employees' termination entitlements at a rate of 50c in the dollar. I am advised that former employees have accepted this offer and some have received their termination payments. Due to the payout of their termination payments, some ex-employees may be subject to an income maintenance period. In some cases, their existing social security payments may be reduced. However, most will have their social security payments suspended for whatever the period.

answer.para: The income maintenance period will apply from the date that the leave payments are made. The income maintenance period provides that any leave payments—for example, annual leave, long service leave and sick leave—paid to a person when they become unemployed are treated as income from the date of payment for a period equal to that covered by the leave. Given that the administrator has provided for leave payments at a rate of 50c in the dollar, the income maintenance period is calculated at a rate that corresponds to half of the dollar amount offered to the miners and for a duration that is equal to the actual period that the leave payments were accrued.

I understand that, subject to decisions of the administrator, these miners may receive the balance of their leave payments at a later date. If that is the case, they will not be subject to a further income maintenance period. As at 26 March 1998, there were approximately 144 cases where an income maintenance period has been imposed.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister did not answer either yes or no, but I take it from the detail that she provided in her answer that she in fact acknowledges that there are a number of miners who have still not received their entitlements to unemployment benefits. Minister, given that you concede that that is the case and that they are faced with the income maintenance test period still having to run out, and given that the Prime Minister has refused to help the sacked miners, will you at least investigate the possibility of providing some assistance through your department to these people who are still waiting for any assistance to come forth?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

I thought he would really be interested in the miners and I gave him all the information I have in my brief. I would point out to him—and I do not have this information here—that all but 10 claims had been granted as at 26 March and I am assuming that those 10 people have been assets tested and found not to be eligible for payment or income tested and may not have been eligible on other grounds.
—The point is there are still people waiting. Are you going to give them assistance in the meantime?

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, is it true that over 55 per cent of the 8,000 multinational or transnational companies in Australia pay no tax? Is it not the case that the tax office is totally incapable of enforcing transfer pricing provisions across these 8,000 companies and that Australia is therefore being robbed blind by many multinational companies not paying their way? What does your government intend to do to stop the loss of hundreds of millions of tax dollars which should be paid by many multinational or transnational companies?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Murray, for that question. Senator Murray—unlike the Labor Party—has shown an interest in tax avoidance issues and, in general, perhaps with one or two exceptions, has been prepared to accept the government's measures in this area which, regrettably, have been frequently opposed by the Labor Party.

answer.para: Senator Murray, in answer to your question, as you are aware, all companies in Australia are subject to an Australian tax of 36 per cent on their taxable income. This applies regardless of whether they are Australian companies or non-resident companies doing business through a permanent establishment in Australia, and regardless of whether they are owned by resident or non-resident shareholders.

Non-resident companies carrying on business through a branch in Australia paid some $295 million in tax in 1995-96—these figures come from the ABS. ABS data on the tax paid by foreign controlled Australian resident companies is not available because those companies are included in the statistics for resident companies. In 1995-96, income taxes levied on resident companies, including petroleum resource rent taxes, amounted to some $17.5 billion.

Non-resident companies investing in Australia while not actually carrying on a business here through a permanent establishment are, unless specific exemptions apply, subjected to withholding taxes on interest payments, dividends or royalties arising from this investment. Withholding taxes levied on non-residents amounted to $1.2 billion in 1995-96.

Senator Murray raised the issue of transfer pricing in his comments, and Australia's tax law requires that transfer prices for transactions between companies doing business in Australia and related offshore entities are set on an arms-length principle. These provisions seek to ensure that manipulation of transfer prices is not used to shift profits out of Australia and so reduce income tax payable in Australia.

Senator Murray asked me to outline some of the government's actions in this area to ensure proper compliance in the payment of taxes. I can advise that, as part of the government's commitment to ensuring that all companies continue to pay their fair share of tax, several measures were announced in the last year or so which further protect Australia's tax base.

These measures include: applying the general anti-avoidance provisions of the tax act to counter withholding tax avoidance; tighter residency laws to stop foreign companies claiming tax advantages as dual residents; tighter thin capitalisation rules; measures to stop tax avoidance through tax exempt entities distributing funds offshore; and measures to prevent franking credit trading and dividend streaming.

I think I have been able to illustrate to Senator Murray and the Senate that the government has taken steps where steps have to be taken to ensure proper compliance and to counter tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. I think the government has a very proud record in this area. I have to say that I wish we had received more support from the Labor Party in countering tax avoidance measures.

talk.start.para: —You're not serious?
—Senator Conroy said that I'm not serious. If there's a supplementary I might show you how serious I am, Senator Conroy.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I recognise the efforts made to date, but I wish to ask a supplementary question on priorities or emphasis. Is it not true that if the government gave half the time and resources to pursuing a number of multinational tax cheats that it devoted to pursuing a number of social security cheats, then Australia would have enough money to solve the health crisis and to reduce its social deficit?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I think that question started off pretty well, actually but, unfortunately, as we got to the second and third sentences, it declined quite rapidly. I welcome the acknowledgment you gave to the actions by the government. That is appreciated. That was the good part of your question. Let me refer to the bad part. In relation to all aspects of the law—whether they be social security laws or tax laws—it is appropriate that governments and their agencies do all that is possible to ensure proper compliance. This is precisely what this government does.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill as the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, do you recall making the following statement to the Senate regarding former Senator Richardson in 1992:

The statement and the standards that the Prime Minister said he stands by require that Ministers disclose other registrable interests so that the public can see that they are not, in dealing with legislation and Cabinet matters, putting themselves in any potential position of conflict.

Minister, do you stand by that view? Minister, don't you agree that if you were to consistently apply the test that you applied to former Senator Richardson in 1992 you would have advised the Prime Minister to terminate Senator Parer's career as a minister?

talk.start.para: —Madam President, on a point of order: in Senator Hill's absence overseas last week, Senator Faulkner asked almost precisely the same question. I therefore ask you whether that doesn't qualify as a classic example of tedious repetition, which clearly demonstrates the bankruptcy of this outfit, which is simply going through the motions.
—There is no point of order.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —I remember a debate concerning Senator Richardson. It concerned the fact, as I recall, that he was a director of a radio station that was owned by the ALP.
—In the Newcastle area.

—A business in the Newcastle area—I think Senator Tierney is familiar with it. He was the minister for communications at the time, as I recall. Am I wrong in that? Anyway, as recall it, he was the minister for communications at a time in which decisions were made by him that could be influenced by the radio station's position. We raised that issue, and we were critical of him. As I recall, that was pursued under the senators' interests provisions.
—It was not in by then.

—I was just wondering that, Senator. It was always so difficult with the ALP because they were reluctant to publish any conditions in relation to conflict of interest. As I recall, Mr Hawke did it at an early stage, but then Mr Keating refused to do it. Presumably Mr Keating refused to do it because of his pig farm interest. So not only was the Labor government under Mr Keating reluctant to disclose the standards but also it thereby put itself in a position where it was difficult to be criticised because it was not prepared to publish the rules.

answer.para: I do recall criticising Senator Richardson for the fact that he did not disclose an interest in that radio station. I thought the criticism at the time was fair and reasonable, and I think it is still the case, and so be it. That was a debate of 1992. If Senator Faulkner is trying to draw some relevance in relation to any matters of current affairs, I can say that under both the senators' interests provisions and the Prime Minister's guidelines, I have not of recent times seen any evidence of conflict of interest.

Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

There were some technical deficiencies at an early stage that have been overcome. They were explained. They largely arose out of ambiguities within the provisions.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment. I refer the minister to the recent announcement that Jandakot Airport Holdings Pty Ltd was a successful tenderer for the lease of Jandakot Airport in the southern suburbs of Perth. I ask: given that Jandakot Airport is situated on the Jandakot water mound, which is an important source of domestic water in Perth, and given the importance of the area for biodiversity, particularly in the form of national estate listed banksia woodlands and wetlands, was the minister consulted during the tender process about the environmental impacts of potential activities of the lessee? If so, what was the nature of the advice? If not, given reports that the successful tenderer is proposing to sand mine the area and also use parts of the hill for landfill, will the minister undertake to conduct an environmental assessment of any proposed commercial activities to be undertaken by the lessee?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —It is true that the government has recently announced that the successful bidder for the long-term lease of Jandakot Airport is Jandakot Airport Holdings, which is a 100 per cent Perth-owned entity comprising three local companies—Soils Ain't Soils, Level Holdings and CGA Services. The bids for the airport were assessed against a range of sales and ongoing regulatory objectives. It was not solely price driven. We closely looked at management capability, financial strength, environment, development and maintenance plans for the airport, treatment of FAC staff and the level of local involvement.

answer.para: I am advised that, in the bid assessment, particular attention was given to the sensitive environmental issues at the airport. As part of their bids, the bidders were required to provide extensive details of their environmental management plans for the airport, including strategies for preventing, controlling and reducing environmental impacts. It was a key evaluation criteria.

Once the airport is leased, the airport will become subject to the requirements of the Airports Act 1996, which sets out a comprehensive regulatory regime for the airport. The act provides that the airport lessee must, within the first 12 months of taking up the lease, submit for ministerial approval an environmental strategy which details how the airport will be operated so that its environ mental health is maintained and improved. The strategy must go out for public comment for at least 90 days prior to being submitted and must reflect how it addresses the public comments raised.

Once the environmental strategy is approved, the act obliges the airport operator to ensure that it is complied with. The act and regulations set stringent standards and impose duties in relation to environmental pollution with heavy penalties for offences, and the Commonwealth will have an airport environment officer at the airport to apply and enforce the standards and penalties under the Airports Act. Additionally, the airport, as a Commonwealth place, will continue to be subject to the full range of Commonwealth laws such as the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, the Endangered Species Protection Act and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act.

If it is intended, as I gather it is, that there will be major developments for the airport, they will require approval under the Airports Act. I have been advised by my colleague the minister for transport that major development proposals of environmental significance will be referred for consideration under the EP(IP) Act.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. So we will look forward to some kind of assessment that we can read. The minister mentioned that one of the major investors in the company that was awarded the Jandakot Airport lease was the well-know soil blending company Soils Ain't Soils, which had been convicted of operating without the necessary permit from the City of Cockburn. It continued to operate in defiance of instructions that it cease operations. The same company stockpiled 30,000 cubic metres of sewage sludge near a water authority bore on the Jandakot mound in 1995 without seeking any authority to do so. Given this record, does the minister not agree that there is substantial ground for investigating by his department of the proposed activities of the new lessee of the Jandakot Airport to ensure that the important biodiversity values and the critical water resource is not adversely impacted?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —I indicated that one of the companies comprising the successful tender was a company called Soils Ain't Soils, so there is no surprise in that. But what I have sought to point out to the honourable senator is the extensive environmental requirements that will be imposed upon the lessee under the terms of the Airports Act. That I think can give the honourable senator considerable assurance that her concerns are misplaced. In addition to that I also said that, if there is any specific significant development or development that has a significant environmental effect, it then runs into the provisions of the Commonwealth EP(IP) Act as well and I will receive advice in due course of appropriate assessment. I do not know about the matters of history to which the honourable senator alludes, but I can tell her from the perspective of the future that the environmental values will be well protected. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, I refer to your answer yesterday to a dorothy dixer from Senator Sandy Macdonald proclaiming the government's commitment to alternative energy sources. Are you aware of a letter from the Liberal member for Gilmore, Joanna Gash, to you dated 13 August 1996 protesting strongly at the proposal to scrap the bounty for ethanol as an alternative fuel source? Didn't Mrs Gash ask, `The least you can do is honour the agreements of the previous government. Would you renege on a contract?' And later, `There are too many arguments against what you are proposing for it to be politically or morally acceptable'? Doesn't this protest from one of the government's own backbenchers demonstrate your own lack of credibility on any issue of renewable energy sources?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —This was canvassed—obviously, Senator Cook was not listening—two years ago after the first budget decision, which I might say was a cabinet decision of the government, bearing in mind that we were confronting a $10.5 billion deficit bequeathed to us by the previous government. So difficult decisions had to be made. This was pursued at great length in estimates committee following that budget. I think it was Senator Woodley who pursued it—it was certainly one of the Democrats.

answer.para: When the government came in it got the whole business of the ethanol bounty reviewed by the department. I think I am correct in saying that it was an interdepartmental committee, but it was two years ago anyway. Quite conclusively, on the advice given to us at the time, this could not be recommended to continue. Also my understanding at the time when it was introduced was that it is was a deal made between the Labor Party and the Democrats to get a budget through. That was always my understanding.

The ethanol bounty was being given to two companies. One was a company in Queensland that had been producing ethanol since I think about 1928, so they thought Father Christmas had come when you introduced that. The other company was at Manildra. It was pursued, as I said, at great length. The purpose of the ethanol bounty was for the mixture of ethanol with petrol. This mix was being used by certain independent companies, mainly in the state of New South Wales. On all the evidence given to me—independently, I might say—by the department, the recommendation was that, in view of the stringent budget circumstances of the time and in addressing the budget deficit, it could not be justified to be continued.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. You said was the question was taken by the cabinet. Are you distancing yourself from that decision? Did not Mrs Gash's letter also state that it has taken years to gain credibility with the community and, `To forsake this for one year of a bounty—when it appears that assurances were given by the Prime Minister to the constituent on this issue—would wound the standing of myself, the Prime Minister and the government'? Minister, isn't the Liberal member for Gilmore correct on that point?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —I was not distancing myself from the decision at all and I did not indicate that I was, Senator. I think you just made that up or, alternatively—
—Read the Hansard . You said it was a decision of cabinet, not yours.

—Well it was a decision of cabinet, but if you look back at when the decision was made, I certainly did not distance myself from it. I would like to commend Mrs Gash because, unlike the Labor Party on the other side, she was representing a constituency and it is her right to do so.

—My question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, the education unions have been distributing misleading material regarding Commonwealth schools funding. Naturally, the ALP has also joined in and made misleading comments about school funding. Would you, Minister, outline where the ALP and others are wrong and inform the Senate as to what the true position is on the coalition's substantial funding to schools?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Calvert for that very good question. There has been a concerted effort by the opposition and the Australian Education Union in a campaign which is most misleading in that it is saying we are drawing funds from the government sector to give to the non-government sector and that we are reducing funding for government schools. Let us put the record straight. Compared with the last year of Labor in power, we have increased funding for government schools to the extent of $127 million. Compared with 1996, that is $127 million more in 1998.
—Is this real prices or—
—Order! Senator Carr, I ask you to cease interjecting. There is an appropriate time for you to debate this issue, and that is later in the day.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I believe that the minister ought not mislead the Senate by presenting figures which are false and misleading.
—Senator Carr, there is no point of order. That is a debating matter that you can take up at the appropriate time. You are in breach of the standing orders.

—Senator Carr well knows that this involves actual expenditure—dollars and cents. It is an increase which in 1999 will involve $146 million more than in the last year of Labor. In the year 2000 it will involve $169 million more than in the last year of Labor. That is all for government schooling. In fact, this campaign is evident in an article entitled `The class divide' in the Herald Sun today, which plays upon the difference between the government and the non-government sector. That article also gets it wrong, because it says that our funding for the government sector is $1.2 billion. This underestimates our expenditure by $300 million. That is just a campaign to mislead and cause alarm in the community.

answer.para: But let us look at what Labor did. Apart from spending less on education, Labor failed to tackle the real issues. It had a new schools policy which stunted the choice available to parents as to where they could send their children. We have abolished that and opened up the opportunity for non-government schools. We allowed choice for the parents of Australia as to where they sent their children. We brought in a program for increasing literacy, which the previous government ignored. We also brought in a civics campaign to deal with Australian citizenship and how our students understood that.

What does Mark Latham, who is the member for Werriwa and the opposition spokesman for education, say in his book? In looking at human capital, which involves the education of the next generation, he said:
Education resources need to be devoted to the competence, skills and personal development of citizens, rather than simply substituting for the short-term training costs of industry.

We have done that. We have looked at things like literacy for personal development of our students. We have looked at the civics which deal with the citizenship that he talks about. We have looked at vocational educational programs in our schools which deal with the skills and development of our students. We have dealt with that. But when you look at his book and go further, where does he deal with it? He doesn't. That is all he says about education, and it is baseless rhetoric. Where is the policy that this opposition has in relation to the specifics which are going to advance the next generation of Australians? When you look at this book written by the shadow minister for education, that is all you get on education. There is nothing about the specifics which are going to advance Australian students.

Not only have we spent more money on education but we have also targeted the specifics that will advance the skills much needed for the next generation to get jobs. We have targeted things like literacy. We have taken on those hard issues which Labor failed to do. But what is more important is that we have given the parents of Australia a choice, which the opposition never did. It stunted that choice with its new schools policy, and we abolished it.

Senator the Hon Margaret Reid
President of the Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
